abstract_summ: METHODS: Here we estimate the effective reproduction number, R(t), of COVID-19 in Singapore from the publicly available daily case series of imported and autochthonous cases by date of symptoms onset, after adjusting the local cases for reporting delays as of March 17, 2020.METHODS: Here we estimate the effective reproduction number, R(t), of COVID-19 in Singapore from the publicly available daily case series of imported and autochthonous cases by date of symptoms onset, after adjusting the local cases for reporting delays as of March 17, 2020.The confidence intervals of the now-casting indicated an increase of cases in the last reporting days, while case country in that same time period suggested a decline.This model is used to forecast Total Covid cases, after cautionary discussion of triggers that would invalidate the model.In reality, the epidemic curve may still be on the rise, because reporting delay prevents the most recent cases to appear in the case count.
title_summ: Now-casting the COVID-19 epidemic: The use case of Japan, March 2020MODELING COVID19 IN INDIA (MAR 3 - MAY 7, 2020): HOW FLAT IS FLAT, AND OTHER HARD FACTSProjections and early-warning signals of a second wave of the COVID-19 epidemic in IllinoisCoViD-19 Epidemic in India and Projections: Is Relief in Sight?Effective immunity and second waves: a dynamic causal modelling studyReal-time monitoring the transmission potential of COVID-19 in Singapore, March 2020Real-time monitoring the transmission potential of COVID-19 in Singapore, March 2020
title_abstract_phrases: METHODS: Here we estimate the effective reproduction number, R(t), of COVID-19 in Singapore from the publicly available daily case series of imported and autochthonous cases by date of symptoms onset, after adjusting the local cases for reporting delays as of March 17, 2020.METHODS: Here we estimate the effective reproduction number, R(t), of COVID-19 in Singapore from the publicly available daily case series of imported and autochthonous cases by date of symptoms onset, after adjusting the local cases for reporting delays as of March 17, 2020.MODELING COVID19 IN INDIA (MAR 3 - MAY 7, 2020): HOW FLAT IS FLAT, AND OTHER HARD FACTSA time-series model was developed for Number of Total Infected Cases in India, using data from Mar 3 to May 7, 2020.This model is used to forecast Total Covid cases, after cautionary discussion of triggers that would invalidate the model.In reality, the epidemic curve may still be on the rise, because reporting delay prevents the most recent cases to appear in the case count.
